multiple_choice_question.text: This formula defines the line element (ds)² for Lie groups. What property of the right-hand side of the equation makes it suitable for representing a line element?
choices: It transforms linearly under global Lie group transformations.
It is always a positive real number.
It is invariant under global Lie group transformations.
It is a quadratic form of the group parameters.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula represents the inverse metric derived from the SU(2) Lie group. Which statement about this metric is TRUE?
choices: It is independent of the parameter |θ|.
It is the inverse of the metric given in formula (10).

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation represents a simplified form of the Einstein equation with a cosmological constant. What does this equation imply about the metric derived from the SU(2) Lie group?
choices: The metric describes a space with constant scalar curvature.
The metric is an Einstein metric.
The metric is only valid locally.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula represents a quadratic invariant form. What is the significance of this invariant form in relation to classical Lie groups?
choices: It defines the structure constants of the Lie algebra.
It defines the set of transformations that leave the form unchanged, thus characterizing the Lie group.
It represents the Killing form associated with the Lie group.
It defines the metric on the tangent space of the Lie group.
